messages.text:
hi guys! I don’t see the history here, so excuse me for asking naive questions!
I’m looking into using Julia extensively in my quant research nowadays, and writing a bunch of functions that I was previously using from the PerformanceAnalytics package in R - that I’m hoping to put in a package soon (or as soon as possible). I’m working with TimeSeries.jl as a base. Is that a better choice, let’s say over Temporal.jl?

elements.text:
hi guys! I don’t see the history here, so excuse me for asking naive questions!
I’m looking into using Julia extensively in my quant research nowadays, and writing a bunch of functions that I was previously using from the PerformanceAnalytics package in R - that I’m hoping to put in a package soon (or as soon as possible). I’m working with TimeSeries.jl as a base. Is that a better choice, let’s say over Temporal.jl?

messages.text: Also, let me know if anyone who would is doing similar work, I’m happy to collaborate!

elements.text: Also, let me know if anyone who would is doing similar work, I’m happy to collaborate!

messages.text: Naive questions? ok. You should (also) ask "I'm happy to collaborate" on Discourse (some overlap, some new looks).

elements.text: Naive questions? ok. You should (also) ask "I'm happy to collaborate" on Discourse (some overlap, some new looks).

messages.text: the two best choices are `TimeSeries.jl` and `Temporal.jl` .. `TimeSeries.jl` is used as a more general purpose analytical tool.  The support for the `Tables.jl` interface is a bonus -- I don't know if both packages provide that support.  `Temporal.jl` is very nice for working with feeds and some prefer its "feel" working with financial market data.

elements.text: the two best choices are

Temporal.jl

messages.text: thanks! hmm yes, I did choose TimeSeries.jl originally because it seemed a bit more actively maintained, and I saw there are packages building on top of it (TimeSeriesResampler.jl, etc.)

elements.text: thanks! hmm yes, I did choose TimeSeries.jl originally because it seemed a bit more actively maintained, and I saw there are packages building on top of it (TimeSeriesResampler.jl, etc.)

messages.text: but it looks like some of these features are built into Temporal.jl

elements.text: but it looks like some of these features are built into Temporal.jl

messages.text: but in reality, it doesn’t matter, to be honest, I’d be happy to support both

elements.text: but in reality, it doesn’t matter, to be honest, I’d be happy to support both

messages.text: I’ll write to Discourse about this!

messages.text:
hi guys! :slightly_smiling_face:
I’ve posted this on discourse, but I thought I’d put it here as well: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/is-anyone-up-for-collaborating-on-a-vectorized-portfolio-backtesing-library/57720>
ping me if you’d want to collaborate on any level! even some review on Julia package conventions could be very useful - this is gonna be my first one!

attachments.title: Is anyone up for collaborating on a vectorized (portfolio) backtesing library
attachments.text: Hi! I just replied on another thread - I’ve started working on a vectorized (both single asset and portfolio) backtesting framework. I think it could be a low hanging fruit (it’s really not rocket science), high leverage project, which can establish some of the primites that other package could be using as well. I’m planning to open my code up as soon as I get a bit more familiar with Julia package creation - hopefully this week. The goal would be to create a simple-to-use portfolio backteste...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Is anyone up for collaborating on a vectorized (portfolio) backtesing library
